Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of 3D Laser Scanner for Research Evaluating Structural and Agronomic Damage from Catastrophic Meteorological Events in "Tornado Alley"

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Acquisition of a FARO X330 laser scanner by West Texas A&M University (WTAMU) through this Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award enables cross-disciplinary researchers to rapidly and accurately collect and preserve perishable damage data resulting from the action of severe wind storms where traditional (contact) measurements cannot be accomplished due to safety concerns or due to limitations on access, time, and personnel. Laser scanning rapidly provides a permanent record of damage conditions for subsequent detailed analysis, including wind-induced damage to structures and thunderstorm-induced damage to agricultural crops. Such analysis of damaged structures enables investigators to determine the intensity of tornado winds since direct measurements of tornado wind speeds are difficult and dangerous to obtain. Wind speeds in the Enhanced Fujita (EF) Scale (the official U.S. measure of tornado intensity) are currently based on only estimates and are in need of validation or revision so that engineers can design structures that provide improved safety, resilience, and economy. Acquisition of the laser scanner postures faculty and students in the young, undergraduate engineering program for increased roles in high-level (inter) national research efforts, aiding the goal of WTAMU (an Eligible Institution under Title III Hispanic Serving Institution) in broadening the participation of underrepresented groups in education and research. Collaboration with other national and international hazards researchers is facilitated by WTAMUs sharing of damage information through the new NSF-sponsored NHERI DesignSafe-ci.org data repository. Interaction between scientists at USDA-ARS Conservation and Production Research Laboratory with undergraduate and graduate students and faculty in engineering and agricultural sciences will additionally be enhanced with this new opportunity.

The laser scanner will be used to acquire comprehensive 3D models of tornado-damaged structures. Measurements of structural member sizes and deformations will be used along with finite-element modeling software to determine the resistance of the structure and the associated wind pressure and wind speed required to produce the observed damages. These results will provide necessary validation or revisions for wind speeds in the EF Scale. The laser scanner will allow investigators to similarly estimate the resistance of hurricane-damaged structures thereby assisting investigators in expanding the EF Scale for use in hurricanes by accounting for the increased resistance of structures along the hurricane coast. Agricultural researchers will use the laser scanner to measure plant growth, density, and canopy cover of multiple High Plains crops with such various treatments as row spacing, water regimen, variety, and nutrient application; the nonintrusive remote measurements allow for simplified and more robust experimental designs. Using research plots at the USDA-ARS Conservation and Production Research Laboratory (CPRL) at Bushland, TX, crop maturation and growth efficiency measured with the scanner can be correlated with mass gain as indicated by the large weighing lysimeters at CPRL It is often not feasible to make actual field measurements of crop damage immediately following severe weather; however noninvasive remote scanning may inform investigators of actual storm damage conditions prior to plant deterioration, possibly leading to more resilient genotypes. This approach is consistent with the general trend of developing precision technology to more efficiently grow crops while at the same time reducing adverse impacts on the environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The acquisition of a FARO X330 laser scanner by West Texas A&M University (WTAMU) has enabled cross-disciplinary researchers to rapidly and accurately collect and preserve perishable damage data resulting from the action of extreme loads (e.g., severe wind storms and vehicle-bridge impacts) where traditional (contact) measurements cannot be accomplished due to safety concerns or due to limitations on access, time, and personnel. Laser scanning rapidly provides a permanent record of damage conditions for subsequent detailed analysis by the investigation team or by other researchers since the data can be readily archived and shared through the NHERI DesignSafe cyberinfrastructure.

Using this instrument, the new WTAMU Wind Hazards Engineering Program directed by Dr. Womble (Principal Investigator) has obtained significant datasets for damage to structures that positions research faculty and students for research collaborations with other academic institutions. Acquisition of the laser scanner has enabled WTAMU researchers to preserve digital 3D representations of structures (including communication towers, pre-engineered metal buildings, light-gauge steel, wood, and masonry structures) damaged by Hurricane Harvey along the Texas coast. The instrument has additionally enabled WTAMU researchers and other research partners to document and study damage to Interstate 40 highway bridge structures in Bushland, Texas, damaged by a fatal collision with a tractor-trailer and an ensuing prolonged fire. The digital likenesses of these damaged structures enable researchers to measure and study deflections and damage patterns to advance the understanding of extreme loading of high winds, impacts, and fire for steel, concrete, masonry, and wood structures.

The instrument has positioned WTAMU researchers to pursue and obtain additional research grants (including RAPID and CAREER awards) and to develop significant collaborative efforts with established engineering programs (e.g., University of Nebraska-Lincoln), all of which have strengthened the research capabilities of the university, the researchers, and the undergraduate students.  These experiences have enabled undergraduate researchers to work in collaboration with graduate researchers from mature research programs and have encouraged the undergraduate students to pursue graduate education and research opportunities, thereby advancing the mission of the university in promoting advanced STEM education throughout a largely rural and underserved region (with WTAMU serving as the nearest engineering program for portions of 5 rural western states).

 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

Laser scanning provides the opportunity to remotely collect high resolution detailed damage information at the nuts and bolts level thereby enabling the accurate modeling of structures to gain enhanced understanding of damage mechanisms and failure loads. The 3D damage reality-capture data acquired using the laser scanner have enabled WTAMU researchers and collaborators to gain a better understanding of the behavior and failure patterns for structures subjected to extreme (above-design-level) impact loads, thermal (fire) loads, and hurricane winds loads. Studies of hurricane-related damages can also assist future investigators in estimating wind speeds in tornadoes based on observed damages. These data also provide valuable damage data for other hazards researchers through dissemination via the NHERI DesignSafe-ci data repository.

 

BROADER IMPACTS

This endeavor has advanced the natural hazards research emphases in the WTAMU School of Engineering as well as the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. This endeavor has substantially benefitted WTAMU?s young and growing undergraduate engineering program by supporting growth of a research emphasis. The instrumentation has served as a basis for additional research proposals, including the awarding of a RAPID Response Grant for the study of damages from Hurricane Harvey along the Texas coast for the PI and a CoPI, and a CAREER award for the PI. The project has involved participation from undergraduate engineering students who have acquired new skills in remote-sensing data collection and analysis. Other undergraduate students have been exposed to the effects of severe wind loading through integrated presentations in structural analysis courses. Middle- and high-school students as well as junior-college students have been exposed to the effects of extreme wind actions through the WTAMU Engineering Summer Camp and ?Discover WT? recruitment events. Regional STEM teachers have also been exposed to the project through a presentation session at the Panhandle Math-Science Teachers Conference. The project has helped to elevate the education of students by exposing them to undergraduate research opportunities at WTAMU and graduate research opportunities at major research institutions.
